impossible.comment: This is a special rule that should be used where no match is desired. It is not a good idea to match something like '1{0}' because in some cases that can result in infinite loops in token generation. So the rule instead matches and impossible expression to allow a match to fail and move to the next token.

docstring-statement.comment: the string either terminates correctly or by the beginning of a new line (this is for single line docstrings that aren't terminated) AND it's not followed by another docstring

patterns.name: keyword.control.import.kscript
patterns.comment: other legal use of `as` is in an import

patterns.name: keyword.control.flow.kscript
patterns.match: (?x) \b(?<!\.)( if | else | while | for | try | catch | finally | assert | throw | ret | cont | type | break | del | import | from | \-\> )\b

member-access-attribute.comment: Highlight attribute access in otherwise non-specialized cases.
member-access-attribute.name: meta.attribute.kscript

special-names.name: constant.other.caps.kscript
special-names.match:
(?x)
  \b
    # we want to see "enough", meaning 2 or more upper-case
    # letters in the beginning of the constant
    #
    # for more details refer to:
    #   https://github.com/MagicStack/MagicPython/issues/42
    (
      _* [[:upper:]] [_\d]* [[:upper:]]
    )
    [[:upper:]\d]* (_\w*)?
  \b

odd-function-call.comment:
A bit obscured function call where there may have been an
arbitrary number of other operations to get the function.
E.g. "arr[idx](args)"

fstring-illegal-single-brace.comment: it is illegal to have a multiline brace inside a single-line string

f-expression.comment: All valid Python expressions, except comments and line continuation

import.comment: Import statements used to correctly mark `from`, `import`, and `as`

generator.comment:
Match "for ... in" construct used in generators and for loops to
correctly identify the "in" as a control flow keyword.

decorator.name: meta.function.decorator.kscript
decorator.end:
(?x)
  ( \) )
    # trailing whitespace and comments are legal
    (?: (.*?) (?=\s*(?:\#|$)) )
  | (?=\n|\#)

call-wrapper-inheritance.comment: same as a function call, but in inheritance context
call-wrapper-inheritance.name: meta.function-call.kscript

function-call.name: meta.function-call.kscript
function-call.comment: Regular function call of the type "name(args)"

patterns.comment: Some color schemas support meta.function-call.generic scope
patterns.name: meta.function-call.generic.kscript

builtin-exceptions.name: support.type.exception.kscript
builtin-exceptions.match: (?x) (?<!\.) \b( ( | OutOfIter | Keyboard)Exception | ( | Internal | OutOfMemory | Todo | Import | Type | Template | Key | Index | Name | Attr | Val | Arg | Size | math | Overflow | Assert | Op | Syntax)Error )\b

patterns.name: support.function.builtin.kscript
patterns.match:
(?x)
  (?<!\.) \b( abs | all | any | call | chr | eval | exec | filter | hash | id | input | issub | iter | len | map | max | min | next | ord | open | pow | print | repr | sum | zip  )\b

builtin-types.name: support.type.kscript
builtin-types.match:
(?x)
  (?<!\.) \b( object | number | bool | int | Enum | float | complex | str | bytes | range | slice | list | tuple | set | frozenset | dict | frozendict | namespace | frozennamespace | graph | frozengraph | function | partialfunction | iostream | FileStream | module | thread | frame | mutex | logger )\b

magic-function-names.comment:
these methods have magic interpretation by python and are generally called
indirectly through syntactic constructs
magic-function-names.match:
(?x)
  \b( __(?:
 template | new | init | free | bool | int | float | complex | number | str | bytes | dict | helpful_attrs | integral | freeze | fmt | getattr | setattr | getitem | setitem | repr | len | hash | iter | next | contains | call | pos | neg | abs | sqig | add | sub | mul | div | floordiv | mod | pow | lt | gt | le | ge | eq | ne | cmp | lshift | rshift | binor | binand | binxor  )__ )\b

magic-variable-names.comment: magic variables which a class/module may have.

illegal-names.match:
(?x)
  \b(?:
( assert | async | await | break | cont | func | type | del | else | catch | finally | for | ∀ | from | global | if | in | ∈ |  throw | ret | try | while | with | yield | as | import )  )\b

illegal-object-name.comment: It's illegal to name class or function "True"
illegal-object-name.name: keyword.illegal.name.kscript

fstring-single-core.name: string.interpolated.kscript string.quoted.single.kscript
fstring-single-core.match:
(?x)
  (.+?)
    (
      (?# .* and .*? in multi-line match need special handling of
        newlines otherwise SublimeText and Atom will match slightly
        differently.

        The guard for newlines has to be separate from the
        lookahead because of special $ matching rule.)
      ($\n?)
      |
      (?=[\\\}\{]|(['"])|((?<!\\)\n))
    )
  (?# due to how multiline regexps are matched we need a special case
    for matching a newline character)
  | \n

fstring-raw-single-core.name: string.interpolated.kscript string.quoted.raw.single.kscript
fstring-raw-single-core.match:
(?x)
  (.+?)
    (
      (?# .* and .*? in multi-line match need special handling of
        newlines otherwise SublimeText and Atom will match slightly
        differently.

        The guard for newlines has to be separate from the
        lookahead because of special $ matching rule.)
      ($\n?)
      |
      (?=[\\\}\{]|(['"])|((?<!\\)\n))
    )
  (?# due to how multiline regexps are matched we need a special case
    for matching a newline character)
  | \n

fstring-multi-core.name: string.interpolated.kscript string.quoted.multi.kscript
fstring-multi-core.match:
(?x)
  (.+?)
    (
      (?# .* and .*? in multi-line match need special handling of
        newlines otherwise SublimeText and Atom will match slightly
        differently.

        The guard for newlines has to be separate from the
        lookahead because of special $ matching rule.)
      ($\n?)
      |
      (?=[\\\}\{]|'''|""")
    )
  (?# due to how multiline regexps are matched we need a special case
    for matching a newline character)
  | \n

fstring-raw-multi-core.name: string.interpolated.kscript string.quoted.raw.multi.kscript
fstring-raw-multi-core.match:
(?x)
  (.+?)
    (
      (?# .* and .*? in multi-line match need special handling of
        newlines otherwise SublimeText and Atom will match slightly
        differently.

        The guard for newlines has to be separate from the
        lookahead because of special $ matching rule.)
      ($\n?)
      |
      (?=[\\\}\{]|'''|""")
    )
  (?# due to how multiline regexps are matched we need a special case
    for matching a newline character)
  | \n
